title: TRUMIT: A Tool to Support Large-Scale Mining of Text Association Rules

author: George Tsatsaronis, Norwegian University of Science and Technology

segmentation: Good afternoon, I'm George has aronis from the biotechnology center located at the Technical University of Dresden in Germany.
Also technology consultant entrance inside game behind this is a joint work with a Norwegian University of Science and technology, namely Robert Neimeyer and Cats in North.
Tom, it is about a fishing Association rule.
Mining from text.
So the basic three novelty Strom it introduces is first of all, the combination or integration of.
As you will see in the next slides, eight different annotators to annotate text with categories and concepts.

Secondly, it's the Association rule extraction itself as the process, both between terms as items and or categories, and finally the incorporation of unsupervised evaluation measures for ranking and evaluating the extracted Association rules.
For example, some combinations of support, the confidence or the use of some measures of semantic relatedness between the concepts.
We have played a bit with the large amount of WikiLeaks documents and the checks haven't document collect.
So this is a short overview of how the architecture works.
It has basically four stages.
The first stage is a very basic preprocessing stage through weeds.
We perform some basic syntax analysis like part of speech tagging and also apply annotation with all.
In our case 8 but can basically expand it to more annotators on text.
Second stage is about filtering out the annotations that the users are.

Do not really care about and then based on this filtering on the output of this filtering, the third date comes which is about the extraction of the Association rules between terms or concepts, and finally the user is able to see the results based on based on the unsupervised measures used for ranking of the rules.
So the methodology is quite simple, straightforward.

I would say for us the transactions comprise the sentences of the text so that there's a sentence splitter, and we're also using an additional set which is the set of all possible annotation types as a result of applying the different annotators and text.
Um, some examples of the term rules can be.
For example, if Google is seen on text, then you might also see with high confidence or support the year 1998.

Or for example, if you meet inside the text name Bill Gates and you might also meet with high confidence that the company name of Microsoft and you can imagine that we can also extract in the same way.
By the way, the algorithm you use for the extraction of the rule is FP growth.
We can also extract Association rules between the categories of the concepts of the terms.
And they just look give you a sort sort summary of ideas of how can we apply the rules into some future work.
These are only eight of the annotators that can be incorporated into the system, so we have incorporated a language annotator.
The open call annotator at public speech tagger.
Basically Stanford Tiger and also the Stanford named entity recognition annotator, the Warden domains Model keyword annotator, electrical.
Generator and the Wikipedia minor.
Under an example of application could be using for for example the parts of speeds you can actually derive patterns adaptive patterns between parts of speech in language.
From which up to now we know exactly how nouns or verbs behave together.

Or another example could be using the Mauian Warden combination to extract patterns between topics, topics and categories or subjects of text and the term Association rules can be definitely used as a future work to extract triplets.
So based on just three screenshots from how the system works and we will be more than glad to meet you downstairs to talk a bit more about our demo.
Thank you very much.
